The object of including the word " probable " in the clause is to make it possible to pass legislation under which, if necessary, compulsive operations of a protective character which might mean interfering with the normal course of life and with the normal liberty of action of citizens, could be taken in anticipation of pending interruption.
- Probability is surely a matter of opinion, and actuality a matter of fact.

- Probability is a matter on which opinions may vary, but is also itself a matter of fact. In the absence of the word " probable " it would be impossible lawfully to preparein advance by taking any compulsive action ; without it the Commonwealth would have to wait until an actual interruption had happened, or until the damage was done.
- In such a matter it is better to be a day too late than a day too early.

- That interjection is directed to the desirability, not of constitutional alteration, but of action at a particular time* Every one will agree that in certain circumstances action might be precipitate and unwise, and I presume that is the point of the right honorable gentleman's interjection. That is a matter of action under legislation passed, and no question arises when we are considering whether a constitutional amendment should be made to enable Parliament and the executive so far as. authorized by Parliament, to determine the proper moment .for action. No constitutional amendment in any form could possibly determine that a particular date was the right or wrong day to act under legislation.

speech.para: The relation of these powers to those of the States is important, and it has been mentioned by the right honorable member for Balaclava. He has referred to what was mentioned specifically in the second-reading debate, namely, that there already exists in section 119 of the Constitution a provision enabling a State to apply to the Commonwealth for protection in the case of domestic violence. This proposal advisedly seeks an additional power for the Commonwealth Parliament, and is not made in ignorance or neglect of the provisions of section 119. That section, however, applies only in the case of domestic violence, and there may be serious interruption to essential services without there being any domestic violence at all. The object of this amendment is to confer power upon Parliament to legislate for such occasions, which might also include: occasions of domestic violence; but this power is advisedly intended to increase the existing power of the Commonwealth to enable the proper authorities - duly authorized under legislation which must pass this House - to act in oases where there is an interruption of essential services, apart altogether from the consideration of the question of domestic violence. The position would then be that in the case of mere domestic violence without any interruption of essential services - when it was a question of preserving order and not of interference with essential services - the Commonwealth would be unable to interfere unless a State applied to it; but if domestic violence or any other cause brought about an actual or probable interruption of essential services, it would be possible for the Commonwealth to intervene if authorized to do so by a statute of this Parliament, and if the authority - probably the Executive of the day - appointed under that statute - subject to certain limitations, thought proper.

talk.start.para: - Where domestic violence is associated intimately with the interruption of an essential service, and the State authority does not desire intervention because it does not consider the matter serious, the Federal authority might interfere. There would then be all the elements of a quarrel.

- That is so, and the circumstances would be for the consideration of the Commonwealth authority. Ii is obvious that' the exercise of authority under legislation passed under these powers would call for the most careful judgment and discretion.
- Do I understand that, under these powers, if domestic violence occurred that did not interfere with essential services, the Commonweal ti*, could not intervene?
- Not under these powers.
- But the Commonwealth could intervene in the interruption of essential services, although there might be no domestic violence?
- That is so. The bill deals with a matter other than domestic violence, but domestic violence may frequently be associated with it.
- If domestic violence involved interference with essential services in a particular case, then the Commonwealth could exercise any powers it liked, including marching armies into a State?
- Under this power the Commonwealth authority would be able to do anything to protect the interests of the public sanctioned by the Parliament. All would depend upon the legislation passed.
- If a State Government were to resist the exercise of this power, the Commonwealth could override it, and, if necessary, take drastic action against it.
- That is possible under our existing powers, but is unlikely to happen.
- It might in respect of State railways.

- It happened in Queensland recently. If the Commonwealth mails are interfered with, there. is no doubt as to the power of this Parliament to protect them, entirely irrespective of the views or resistance of any State. But difficulty in that respect will not arise in a sensible community. All the powers of the Commonwealth are overriding, whether they are exclusive or concurrent. Where the Commonwealth power is exercised it is superior to the State power. Adi the Commonwealth powers are over-riding and superior powers, and, with every power which exists, the possibility of conflict occurs. One of the fundamental functions of government is to provide for the security of the people with as little confusion as possible. One of the most urgent considerations for any Commonwealth government would be whether it was 01 was not desirable to intervene in a particular case. The power taken would be one which must be used with commonsense, and only when an emergency was apparent. Honorable members, including the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt), who desire full power to be given to the Commonwealth in matters of trade and commerce, really desire this Parliament te take powers which include those now proposed, and a great deal more. If the Commonwealth is given power to legislalate on all matters relating to trade and commerce, .every ordinary service, and all essential services of the community are comprehended. Full power to legislate in matters of trade and commerce would give the Commonwealth full power to conduct and to protect essential services, and to use force in order to secure their continuance in a way which Parliament thought fit to authorize. Every honorable member who supported the amendment in favour of granting the Commonwealth full power to legislate in regard to matters of industry and commerce is, in effect, supporting this restricted provision and a great deal more.

. - It is to be regretted that the Government should persist in endangering the acceptance of the other proposals for amending the Constitution by tacking on to them this most unpopular one. Without in any way detracting from the cogency of the speeches of honorable members on this side of the chamber, in opposition to the bill, I am sure the committee felt that the Prime Minister's speech had done more to prevent the acceptance of these proposals than anything said on this side df the chamber. I say that with a knowledge of the fact that, however we differ from him politically, we are all disposed to give him credit for clarity and capacity to state a case, so that it can be understood by the House and by the people. There was, however, an obvious desire on his part to avoid the impossible task of explaining what was really meant by the proposal contained in the bill. In a cross-fire of interjections, he made it evident that he proposed to leave the ques-. tion of definitions to Parliament, which would be called upon to legislate, not with the responsibility of framing the Constitution, but in the exercise of the nebulous powers given under the Constitution. Such a procedure is an inversion of the correct process. I remind the Prime Minister, at this stage, late as it is; that we have now to take the responsibility of submitting to the people proposals for the inclusion in the Constitution of terms which we at least pretend to understand. In reading through the Constitution, we find on the face of it at all events, that its terms and powers are clear and unambiguous. In some instances, they are so general and so complete as to leave no room for doubt, and. in others they are couched in such a way that most persons would consider them easily understood. Notwithstanding that, it has been our unfortunate and costly experience that they have been the subject of almost endless and continuous litigation in the High Court. In a short bill, consisting of two clauses, this Government has taken the responsibility of proposing to include a power almost every term of which ia not only ambiguous,, that is, capable of two meanings, but susceptible to so many meanings that it will lead, to uncertainty, delays, expense and endless litigation. We have, therefore, to remember that this proposal is not merely to give the Commonwealth powers in a new, peaceful, and enlarged field, but one which envisages - if it envisages anything at all - an attack upon the liberty of the subject, and pre-supposes the exercise of force upon a section or sections of the people. It necessarily involves litigation and expense and all sorts of unforeseen and un- forseeable consequences. Anything that we, in Parliament, can do hereafter cannot help to clarify the meaning of the words embodied in the Constitution. These words will remain as the constitutional power. Anything we say as to what Parliament intended cannot greatly affect the meaning given to the provisions of the Constitution. The words will be read for what they are, and will eventually be understood in the way they are interpreted by a qualified interpreter of the Constitution. The right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt), in his cogent speech, went to the end of the clause to deal with the question of essential services, and the reply of the Attorney-General (Mr. Latham), which I submit was not worthy of the Minister's position and attainments, was that any word we take, looking at it from the view-point of the philologist or the historian, . opens up an interesting question as to its meaning, but here the question is not merely academic or historical ; it involves the probable exercise of force and seizing State or private property in the interests of the whole community. Taking the first word of the clause, what is meant by "protecting"? I suggest that the word should be interpreted widely, and that it means the exercise by the Government of any power or force to protect, according to its views of protecting. The Government may employ the Naval and Military Forces to the utmost in any part of Australia for the purpose of exercising this protection. The right honorable member for Balaclava referred to section 119, which relates to domestic violence, and the Attorney-General, under criticism, admitted that if domestic violence caused interference with any essential service of the Commonwealth, protection of the interests of the public might possibly involve the use of the military within the borders of a State.
- Commonwealth intervention by some force would be involved.

- This proposal would justify the passing of laws which would permit the intervention of the Commonwealth with any kind of force that the Government could command, including the military and naval powers.' That that is so was illustrated by the Attorney-General a few days ago, when he pointed out that the doctrine of implied prohibition had been set aside in the Engineers' case, and that, therefore, other passages in' the Constitution, which defined a certain scope of military operations in connexion with the defence power, so long as they did not actually prohibit the use of that power on the lines now found necessary for protecting the public, would permit it to be used for the protection of the interests of the public to any extent that the word "protect" implied. Therefore, when we embody in the Constitution a provision that the Commonwealth Government may protect the public interests in connexion with essential services, it follows that the Government could employ any kind of force necessary for such protection. If we pass the necessary legislation, the Commonwealth can invade the States whenever, in the opinion of the Government of the day, an essential service is being interrupted. If my. view of the meaning of protecting is accepted, this legislation would abrogate that provision in the Constitution which declares that the interference of the military in connexion with domestic trouble must be preceded by a request from the State Government. The Attorney-General said that the powers that are to be vested in the Commonwealth can be exercised bv the State already. That is merely a truism. All the powers not enumerated in the Constitution as belonging to the Commonwealth can be exercised by the sovereign State Parliament, just as the British Parliament, being unrestrained by a written Constitution, may legislate in regard to anything and everything within the United Kingdom. Of course, the States can legislate in regard to the matters with which this bill deals, but the Commonwealth powers are defined by a Constitution that is written .and limited, and, therefore, must be strictly construed by its interpreters. I said on an. earlier occasion that I am not at all concerned with the possibility of certain powers being exercised by a non-Labour Government to the detriment of the Labour movement. If I am satisfied that any proposed amendment of the Constitution either adopts the Labour policy of unification with delegated powers to provincial authorities, or, on the other hand, preserves the Federal principle, as this Government proposes to do, and respects the rights of the State sovereign governments to administer their own affairs - if I am convinced, also, that such proposed amendment is permanent and comprehensible and widens our power, I shall accept it. But this proposed amendment responds to none of those tests. It is not comprehensible; it is ambiguous in its every term - as to the meaning of " protecting," as to the meaning of " the interests of the public," as to the meaning of " actual or probable," as to what constitutes an " interruption," and, finally, as to what is meant by "an essential service." The reason why these ambiguities are so peculiarly objectionable is that if this power is to be used at all it must be employed in legislation which will involve impingement upon a particular sphere now occupied by the State authority, and will most likely involve an exercise of force upon certain sections of the community. That being so, it is immensely more important that the language should be clear. If the proposal were for a' mere extension of Commonwealth power in some pacific arena of activities, such as bankruptcy, or bills of exchange, we could proceed with the comfortable feeling that it would involve only a delicate question of the meaning of words, and not a convulsion such as the exercise of these powers may involve. I am greatly disappointed that the Government intends to submit to the people this proposal, which is so distasteful to the Labour party, simultaneously with the one that we have agreed to support. Insofar as those industrial powers are concerned, we have declared ourselves favorable, and it is my intention to support the granting of' them wholeheartedly, for I believe in them, and I have expressed that belief to the head of the Government, who has to some extent acted upon it. But I tell him that it will greatly hamper the passage of those far-reaching and vital amendments for which this Commonwealth has thirsted for many years, to attach to them these distasteful propositions for which in 25 years this Commonwealth has discovered no need whatever, except in the two doubtful cases where the Prime Minister, as I think, arbitrarily and improperly trespassed on the sovereign rights of a State Government in the discharge of duties which were peculiarly its own, and not within the ambit of the Commonwealth's legitimate powers. Apart from that, nobody who knows anything of the history of this Commonwealth can say that there has been any need for this drastic power which it is now proposed to embed in the Constitution. Notwithstanding the difference of opinion among Government supporters as well as among Labour supporters, I venture to say that when the proposals for enlarged industrial power are taken to the country, as they will be, by men sent into this Parliament with the responsibility of understanding propositions of the kind, and advocating them when they do understand them, they will be carried by an overwhelming majority; but I am equally certain that the attachment of this proposal to them will diminish by many thousand votes the support they will receive, though I do not say that that is justified or right.
- Does the honorable member believe that without this bill there is a chance of them being carried?
- I think that there is an excellent chance. A great deal of misunderstanding will soon be swept away in regard to the matter.
- That will.be so if the honorable member does what he says he will do.

- I assure the right honorable gentleman that instead of certain members of this party suffering at the hands of other members of it for their advocacy of these industrial proposals, a great deal of the uncertainty that at present exists will shortly be removed. The misunderstanding will be dispelled without any members of the party being expelled. When, at the end of this week. I am required to expound the industrial proposals of the Government, which I have pledged myself to support wholeheartedly, I shall have to add to my address a wholehearted condemnation of this proposal, for the reasons I have mentioned. My conviction is hardening, with further consideration and discussion, that these essential service proposals are bound to create, not only ill feeling, but uncertainty from the point of view of honorable members opposite, who see in them an intention of the Government to pass legislation which will lead to arbitrary Commonwealth interference with a number of State activities; and from the point of view of honorable members on this side of the chamber, who see in them an intention by the Commonwealth to exercise arbitrary powers, the need for which has not been proven in Federal history. At least, the Government might have postponed the consideration of this matter. I suggest that the principal reason for the Prime Minister pushing on with the dis- cussion to-night is that he has sensed that the desire of honorable members for these powers has diminished, under the criticism and discussion that the proposal has encountered. Every day there is less probability of it being finally accepted. It is not necessary for the bill to be sent on to the Senate to-morrow. If the Senate gives adequate and fair treatment to the industrial powers proposal that has already been sent on to it, it will have enough to occupy its attention for several days.
- I suggest that the honorable gentleman is rather trespassing on the arrangement of his colleague.
- I am in accord with what the Leader of the Opposition said.

speech.para: Mr.Watt. - Is this another pact?

talk.start.para: - The Leader of the Opposition said that the bill would be passed to-night.
- Are these undertakings in writing ?
- We do not need to have them in writing.
- The right honorable gentleman should tell us what has happened.
- The right honorable member knows all about it.

- Honorable members of the Labour party are quite agreeable to postpone further consideration of the bill until to-morrow, but I suggest that it would be of greater advantage to the nation if the Prime Minister would postpone it for 24 years, instead of 24 hours.

.We are not dealing with an ordinary legislative measure, which we can amend next year if we wish to; but with a proposal that may become and remain part of our Constitution for many years. I listened with interest to the important issues raised by the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt). As a layman I was impressed by his statement, and the Attorney-General (Mr. Latham) should not have treated it lightly. Apart from the ambiguity of the words " essential" and " probable," I think that the important point raised by the right honorable member was that the Government was asking for power that would conflict with a provision that has always been embodied in the Constitution.

- The question that was raised by the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt) is worthy of more consideration than is likely to be given to it. It is a great pity that after a quarter of a century, without any material alteration of our Constitution, we cannot deal fully and completely with its amendment in a proper constitutional session, allowing ample time for consideration and discussion. Rush legislation has cost Australia a great deal of money, and the hasty passage of this bill, which is to be submitted to a referendum of the people, will be a very serious matter for this Parliament and for Australia. This is the manner in which legislation has been passed through this chamber at certain times during the last four years. Invariably they have been taxation measures, and our experience has been that annually the Government has had to come down with amending legislation to correct the mistakes that have been made. It will not be possible, however, to do that in this case, because whatever amendments are agreed to by the people will be embedded in the Constitution. The right honorable member for Balaclava raised the point that this power will interfere and conflict with section 119 of the Constitution. I listened attentively to the Attorney-General in reply, but he did not meet the point which had been raised. I am unable to see how it will be possible to reconcile the two conflicting sections of the Constitution. I gathered from the explanation which was given by the Attorney-General that we shall still retain section 119, which empowers the Commonwealth to intervene at the request of a State in case of domestic violence. Paragraph vi. of section 51 empowers the Commonwealth to use the Defence forces to uphold Commonwealth laws. Now we are asked to take a power which will permit this Parliament to use all the forces that are at its command to intervene in an emergency to uphold laws that we have not the power to make, and in so doing to invade State territory. The peculiarity to me is that we should ask for power to enforce laws that we have not the power to make.
- I do not understand the matter in that way.

- The Attorney-General said that we have the power to enforce our own laws in any State, but we have not the power to enforce other than Commonwealth laws unless the State requests us to do so. Therefore, this bill has been brought down to give us the power to deal with matters upon which we have not the power to legislate. We on this side last week urged the Government to take full trade and commerce powers, which would have enabled the Commonwealth Parliament to legislate upon any of those subjects. Having the power to pass any law dealing with trade and commerce, it would have had the power to enforce that law without seeking any emergency power under the Constitution. The Attorney-General twitted this party by stating that these powers were contained in the proposed amendments of the Labour party to the previous bill. We admit it; we advised him to that effect at the time. Our objection rests upon the fact that, although the Government is not prepared to trust itself or this Parliament with full trade and commerce power, it asks us to trust it -with that- extent of power in time of emergency. If we are not prepared to take the power to legislate, in time of peace or war, over the whole field of trade and commerce, we should not seek to interfere in times of emergency with State laws relating to trade and commerce. We on this side are not taking up a position of inconsistency; that is the role of honorable members opposite. The Attorney-General said that if we took the full trade and commerce powers asked for by the Opposition, the Commonwealth would have the power to legislate upon every phase of trade and commerce. Our answer to that" contention was that it did not necessarily follow that all the powers which were taken would be exercised. The Government scouted that argument, and asked, " Why do you want to take powers that may not be used?" When the Prime Minister (Mr. Bruce) was shown what could be done under this bill he replied, "You can take any necessary powers, though they may never be used."
- That is the case with a number of powers which the Constitution originally gave to the Commonwealth Parliament.

- Precisely. Some of the- powers in the Constitution have never been used, and others have been used only partially. No Parliament exercises to the fullest extent the powers that are conferred upon it by its Constitution. That would apply with equal force if full powers over trade and commerce were taken. The principal consideration, however, is that this Parliament ought to make it impossible for its laws to be upset by litigation which raises the constitutional issue. We ought to place our acts beyond doubt, and that can be done in only one way. It is not necessary for one to be a constitutional lawyer to show the way in which our laws may be placed beyond doubt. It can be done only by taking full and complete powers over a particular field of operations. If full constitutional power were taken, the' only scrutiny would be that directed to the verbiage of the acts of Parliament passed under the power, and if that were ambiguous, it could be altered by later acts. The solution of the difficulty will not be found by deleting or defining this or that word in the bill, but by conferring upon this Parliament full power over trade and commerce. I know that an honorable member opposite may say that my attitude is inconsistent because I have objected to this bill for the reason that it seeks to empower the Commonwealth to send the military into a State. I object to this bill because it does not take power to. pass laws that we, on this side, believe will be' of lasting benefit to the community, and takes a power which the Government thinks it can use to the detriment of the workers. We are bold enough to say that we will take the risk of what the Government may do under this power to the detriment of the people if the power is made wide enough to enable us to do good under it, so that, in the long run, it will benefit Australia. I join with the honorable member for Batman (Mr. Brennan) in saying that I am going on to the public platform to fight for the proposals in the other bill. I shall explain those proposals 'as they affect the interests of the people, and I shall do that irrespective of what any one may think. To legislate for the good of the people of this country, this national Parliament must have wider powers.
- Does the honorable member suggest that his is the only party that seeks to do good to the people?
- I do not say that, but there are solid grounds for suspicion as to how a power like this will be used.
- That depends on how suspicious the honorable member's mind is.

- I regret having to be suspicious about anything; but I am one of those who profit by experience. I am always prepared to see, so' far as I am able, the best that is in every person and every party, but I judge people by their actions rather than by their professions, and I remind the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. G. Francis) that before he saw the inside of this Parliament we had to fight this Government for the liberties of the people. The Government may boast about what it did at the election, but the decision of the High Court vindicated, and coming generations will approve, the attitude of the Opposition.
- Would not the long view of which the honorable member has spoken, apply to this bill also?

- The honorable member means that if the power asked for under this bill were given, a Labour Government could exercise it. I took that view of the other measure because it relates to a power to pass laws of a permanent character, whereas this bill gives power to deal only with emergencies. What could the Labour party do under it? We could do to the employing class what we fear this Government may do to the working class. If there was a lockout we could seize the property of the employers and run their businesses. That consideration affords very little satisfaction if one takes the long view and ' seeks to legislate permanently in the interests of Australia. That reminds me of a question I wish to submit to the Prime Minister. When speaking on this bill to-night, he said that the Government would deal with every section of the community impartially. Does he stand by that statement? If he does, let him answer my question. If there is a proba bility of a disturbance, or a cessation of essential services, and he is satisfied that it is due to the employers locking out their men or making their conditions insufferable - if, for instance, the mine-owners say to the miners, " You shall not come into these mines except under certain conditions " which even this Government considers intolerable - will he be prepared to use this power to the extent of seizing the mines and working them in the interests of the essential services of this country? That can be done, and would be done, by a Labour Government under this power. But I say to the honorable member for Gippsland (Mr. Paterson), that is only a passing phase. It is not sufficient ground for altering the Constitution. We have met the Government frankly and said, "You can have full powers for this Parliament if they are permanent powers, and are not merely confined to dealing with emergencies here and there."
- Does not the honorable member regard this as a permanent power, just as section 119 of the Constitution is a permanent power, although it can be exercised only occasionally?

- The power referred to by the right honorable gentleman is permanently in the Constitution until the Constitution is altered, but it is not operated permanently. Section 119 merely relates to the moving of military forces in times of violence; but the power in this bill goes farther than that. It is a temporary power over trade and commerce, to be used only in emergencies for the maintenance of essential services.
- So is section 119 of the Constitution.
- That relates merely to military force. It provides that certain action may be taken on the invitation of a State in the event of domestic violence.
- The protection need not necessarily be by military force. It might be by some other method.

- The right honorable the Prime Minister is simply quibbling. In what other way could or would the section be used? Has it ever been suggested that it would be used in any other way? The Prime Minister said that this appeal to the country had not been sprung upon this Parliament, because he had given notice of it on the 28th August, 1925, when he publicly stated that if the necessity arose he would go to the people and ask for greater powers. If we are to believe the Prime Minister and his supporters, there never was a graver period in the history of Australia than that of the last election. According to their platform speeches, we were then in the throes of a rebellion. Surely, that was the time to ask for greater powers.
- It was only probable, then.

- I accept the definition of the word " probable," but that qualification was not used on hundreds of platforms from which the Nationalist candidates spoke during the election. If the Prime Minister had then placed before the people a proposal to amend the Constitution, instead of waiting until now to introduce this bill, he would have saved this country Â£100,000 of public money. We had a lecture to-night from the Prime. Minister in most offensive terms. He said, " Not one member of the Opposition believes one word of the things he says." An insult could not be couched in more offensive terms than that. One is competent to say that a man's opinion is wrong, and to use quite a number of hard words about him, but to say that the utterances that honorable members make on the floor of the House are nob believed by themselves, is a charge of hypocrisy and lying that has been flung across this chamber on more than one occasion by the Prime Minister. I have made hard statements against actions of this Government, aud I shall do so again if necessary. I have supported this Government in some of its actions, and will do so again if I think fit; but I have never made use of such insulting terms as those used by the Prime Minister respecting honorable members on this side. He also said that the States could deal with profiteering, and that such action was not the function of this Governments I would inform him that the State Governments oan -deal with domestic violence within their own borders more effectively than could the Commonwealth even under these powers. If the Prime Minister were familiar with the subject of profiteering and the powers of this Parliament, aud if he read the opinions expressed by constitutional lawyers for many years past, he would know that neither this Parliament nor the State Parliaments, have power to deal with profiteers. Sir William Irvine, the present Chief Justice of Victoria, pithily said in 1910, during a debate in this House, that in dealing with trusts, combines, and monopolies, and great aggregations of capital, the 'arm of the State was too short, while the arm of the Commonwealth was paralysed by the constitutional ligature that bound it. Although the Commonwealth and the States have not the power to grapple with this problem, yet the Government is not now proposing to take complete power; because without trade and commerce powers the scope of the activities of the Commonwealth is considerably limited. Queensland is the only State that has complete power within its own jurisdiction. The other States are hampered by Legislative Councils supported by privilege and monopoly. We shall not deal -effectively with this problem, even with the additional power to carry on essential services, until we have complete control over trade and commerce. This bill, if given effect, will never be of any permanent use to this country. Its submission to the people will only endanger the bill that was passed last week, which, if given effect, would prove beneficial. As the honorable member for Batman said, when speaking on the platform, we shall support the bill' that confers permanent powers on this Parliament to deal with matters affecting industry and commerce, and strongly oppose this bill, which savours of class legislation. If the' referendum fails because of linking the two proposals together the responsibility will rest upon the Government. It should withdraw this bill and bring down a measure asking for full powers over trade and commerce, so that we may make laws for the benefit of the people of Australia. I agree with the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt) that while the States have sovereign powers we must respect them. I do not believe in having seven sovereign powers in Australia, because the time has come when we should have one. sovereign power. We must, however, respect the principles of the Constitution. Although we have the right to ask the people to enlarge our constitutional powers, we should do nothing to conflict with the sovereign rights of the States until they are merged into one sovereign power.

talker.role: Prime Minister and Minister for External Affairs
talker.name: BRUCE, Stanley
Mr BRUCE

talk.start.para: . - The bill consists of one effective clause, and presents the same opportunity for discussion in committee as it did on the second reading; yet, as the measure was very fully discussed on the motion for the second reading, there is no occasion for honorable members to deliver lengthy speeches on it now. I therefore do not propose to deal with earlier statements which have been repeated; I shall confine myself to the somewhat definite action taken by the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt), who has suggested a certain amendment, and has directed attention to some points in regard to the actual wording of the contemplated amendment of the Constitution, which he suggests requires the fullest consideration. I listened to the speech of the right honorable member with a great deal of attention, as I always do, and he presented his points to the committee with such conviction and command of language as to make his arguments seem unchallengeable. After analyzing his statements, however, one must conclude that he approached the consideration of this clause from a wrong angle. The right honorable member raised certain points concerning the meaning of the word " essential," and of the undesirability of including the words "or probable " in the proposed amendment of the Constitution. He also dealt with the possibility of the provision conflicting with section 119 of the Constitution. His objections are not as serious as he obviously thought them to be. He said that many meanings may be attributed to the word " essential," and asked what it meant in this proposal. The right honorable gentleman will admit that it would be impossible to frame any provision - an amendment of the Constitution or any other - in such a way that the meaning of any word in it would have only one meaning assigned to it in a dictionary. The measure is merely to give the Commonwealth power under which it may legislate; it is not the legislation under which the executive would act. The meaning of " essential services," as used in this instance, is as clear as it is possible to express any meaning in the English language, short of defining every conceivable service that might be em braced by the term. The use of these words will not open the door to litigation or to the challenging of the powers of the Commonwealth in the High Court, because upon the words " essential services," under which power is being taken, it will be necessary for this Parliament to legislate. There is a marked distinction between the words " essential services " in a section of the Constitution and in an act of this Parliament purporting to provide for the exercise of the powers granted. The meaning of " essential services " is clear, and the Commonwealth Parliament in its legislation would unquestionably keep within the recognized limits of what those words could conceivably mean. I cannot appreciate the danger the right honorable member feels in this regard.
- Cannot the right honorable gentleman state the objective in his mind when he is employing the words " essential services " ?

- The provision is to give to Parliament the power to legislate in regard to essential services. I do not suggest for a moment that this proposal, if adopted, will not give the Commonwealth power ' to legislate over a very wide sphere. Parliament in its legislation would have to strain the interpretation of " essential services " to an extraordinary and almost incomprehensible degree before the High Court could declare invalid an act in which those words were used.
- The Commonwealth might exercise its powers by administrative, act, and instanter a case would be taken to the High Court.

- That is not the point I am making. It is almost inconceivable that this Parliament would endeavour to legislate in regard to something so foreign to any possible interpretation of " essential services " that the High Court would be compelled to upset its legislation. It can be said that the power we are seeking is very wide: but some honorable members have not hesitated to suggest that the Commonwealth should have even wider powers in regard to matters, relating to trade and commerce. If such powers were granted, we could do 'everything contemplated under this measure. and might, in fact, come into more serious conflict with the States than is possible under this proposal. I remind the right honorable member for Balaclava that by agreeing to the second reading of the bill this House declared its opinion that the Commonwealth Parliament should be invested with power to legislate upon this subject. The clause under consideration confers a wide power, but it expresses the Government's desire that the Commonwealth Parliament shall have authority to take action when the community is being deprived of services that are essential to the national life. Therefore, I see no danger in the word " essential." Another objection advanced by the right honorable member is that the words "or probable" open up a new menace, and should be omitted. I suggest that those words are necessary to carry out the intention of the House, namely, that if the people are in danger of being deprived of an essential service the Commonwealth must have power to intervene effectively. Suppose that an interruption of the supply of a commodity that was vital to the life of a community - milk, for instance - seemed probable, that the State authority was not prepared to take steps to maintain the service, and that the Commonwealth, in its wisdom, or lack of wisdom, determined that it must act; it could not on the instant organize the supply of that commodity after a complete disruption of the service. The Commonwealth must have power to organize in anticipation of a stoppage ; it must be able to commandeer transport, and make other arrangements, so that it can function the moment the crisis arises and before the service has been seriously dislocated. It cannot afford to defer its organization until a vital service has been withdrawn for a week. If its intervention is to be effective, the Commonwealth must be able to anticipate a probable " interruption of any essential service." Therefore, unless the words " or probable " are retained, the Commonwealth will be practically impotent. Probably the most serious objection to the provision that has been raised is the possibility of conflictbetween the Commonwealth and the State. We have been told that this proposed additional power might come into direct conflict with section 119, by which the Commonwealth may, upon the request of the State, intervene in a domestic disturbance. That danger exists to-day in > ''connexion with

speech.para: Mr. Bruce. the interference with mails, quarantine, Customs, or other Commonwealth services. In regard to interstate trade and commerce, this Parliament can legislate as it thinks fit, and any of its laws might lead to a conflict with a State. These dangers would be present in a much aggravated form if this Parliament possessed that complete power over trade and commerce which honorable members opposite advocated in connexion with the previous referendum bill.

talk.start.para: -. - But there would have been no ambiguity if our amendment had been accepted.

- There would be the same possibility of' conflict, because the Leader of the Opposition suggested that the Commonwealth should take, not exclusive powers, but concurrent powers. With two authorities exercising legislative authority in regard to trade and commerce, the possibility of conflict between Stale and Commonwealth jurisdictions would have been greatly increased. It is for Parliament to decide that the Commonwealth authority shall go to the assistance of the nation when its intervention is necessary for the maintenance of vital services. The power must be expressed in the general and comprehensive words used in the clause, but it will be for Parliament to determine in subsequent legislation how the power shall be exercised. Much has been said regarding what might be done by a government armed with this power of intervention, but I remind the committee that no government can march ahead of public opinion. Only when the public is definitely in favour of a certain course of action by the superior authority, which in this instance is the Commonwealth, can such action be taken. The Government maintains that the power now sought should be vested in the superior authority, the Commonwealth. Its exercise will be controlled by Parliament when legislating specifically under its general constitutional authority, and will at all times be conditioned and safeguarded by public opinion.
- For three years between elections public opinion is inarticulate except through the press.

- In any crisis which affects the lives of the people and the vital industries of the country, public opinion is not inarticulate; at such a time the will, of the people can be ascertained very easily. I think the honorable gentleman will agree with me that a Government cannot, without serious consequences, march ahead of public opinion, in exercising a great power like this. The points that the right honorable member for Balaclava has raised are pertinent to the clause, but it is' not necessary to look at the matter from his point of view. These are only general constitutional powers, under which this Parliament will enact legislation; but they are quite definite and specific. It is clear how far the Commonwealth may safely exercise them. The only way the Government could come into conflict with the High Court in regard to them would be by performing some executive act in connexion with an industry which could not be regarded as essential in the ordinary acceptation of the language in which the clause is couched. The honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Scullin) asked me to say specifically whether, if the coal-mines were closed down because the owners had locked out the miners, the Government would immediately take them over and operate them. It appears to me that the honorable member is confusing two distinct matters. The industrial powers measure was designed to- improve our methods of determining the relations between employers and employees. Even at this moment the coal-mining industry has a tribunal functioning under an act of this Parliament, for the purpose of ensuring fair, equitable, and decent conditions for the miners. It is quite inconceivable that the Government should step in where there was a dispute on a definite finding of the tribunal; its function is to see that the determination of the tribunal is obeyed by both employees and employers, and that no essential service of the people is being interrupted. Legislation will be passed by this Parliament to govern every action that may be taken under these powers, and every case will be dealt with on its own merits.
- The Prime Minister has not answered a straightforward question.

- I think my answer was perfectly clear and definite. If any service of this country, which is essential and vital to the people, was interrupted by strike, lockout, or any other cause, it would be the function of the Government to take action to protect the interests of the public and to restore it,, whoever might be responsible for its interruption. Obviously much thought is being given to this bill. Many statements have been made during our debate on it and on the preceding measure, to the effect that nobody should hesitate to repose, unlimited power in this Parliament. It has been said that it must be assumed that Parliament will make, proper use of whatever power the people give itf. Honorable members opposite who have fought strenuously and nobly for that principle, are. now saying that they will not grant this power to Parliament, for it might be abused. Their position appears to me utterly illogical.
- The 'Prime Minister has placed himself in an awkward position by refusing Parliament the freedom to discharge its industrial authority.

- I disagree with the right honorable member. We have taken full and direct legislative power to create authorities to deal with every phase of the industrial situation. Our powers cover trusts, combines and corporations, as well as trade unions and associations

speech.para: Df employers and employees.

talk.start.para: - A debenture has already been issued for our industrial power; it is not ours.

- It is ours ; but we shall exercise it in a certain way. The honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Scullin) took considerable exception to some, rer marks that I made in replying to the second-reading debate on this bill. If I hurt his feelings, or those of any other honorable member, I am extremely sorry. But "the honorable member is a little too sensitive. He appears to have overlooked the fact that he. and some of his distinguished colleagues have said a good many unpleasant things about myself, and at times have suggested that I have not scrupled to descend to motives and actions that are not proper or befitting the Prime Minister of this great Commonwealth. I assure the honorable member that I am often rather amazed at my own moderation in reply.

.The Prime Minister made a good many remarks about public opinion; but I venture to say that, if the public as a whole could have sat in the gallery and listened to this, debate, it would have damned this bill from the moment of its introduction. The longer the debate proceeds the greater becomes the confusion of honorable members opposite as to the meaning of the words in this clause. Whilst I have no desire to improve this measure for guillotining trade unionism, I think the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt) is to be commended for his amendment to the clause. The Prime Minister has absolutely evaded the fundamental objection of honorable members on this side of the chamber to the bill. We allege that it is an attempt to engraft on our Constitution a form of industrial conscription which is entirely foreign to it. There is no guarantee in the Constitution against any interference with the liberty of the subject, and if this power is invested in the Government it will be exercised regardless of individual liberty. Unlike the American Constitution, which protects every citizen from the suspension of habeas corpus, and from bills of attainder, and in other respects ensures the liberty of the individual against . tyranny, there is nothing in the Commonwealth Constitution that will guarantee individual liberty. If this power is conceded to the Government it can, and no doubt will, abuse it. It has been pointed out that the Opposition's fundamental objection to the bill is the fact that full power over trade and commerce is not sought. The Government has agreed to seek power over trusts and combinations in restraint of trade and power to legislate in regard to corporations. Already the Parliament has power over various agencies and instruments of trade and commerce, but I cannot understand why the Government still obstinately refuses to take the bold and impartial course of asking the people to give the' Parliament the fullest measure of control over trade and commerce. It does not follow that if that step were taken, the Parliament would exercise the powers granted. If the Government took the bold step of accepting the proposals previously submitted to the people and embodied them in the present bill, much of the criticism advanced against this clause would be answered. I submit that the power to legis late should be couched in explicit and unambiguous language. It has already been clearly shown that the words in the clause are capable of a hundred and one different interpretations. The term " protecting the interests of the public " requires explanation. Does that "protection " go to the length of including the arbitrary imprisonment of persons, the use of military forces to suppress disorder, suspension of the right to trial by jury, and the deportation of citizens on any pretext that the Government may think fit? What actually is the power to be invested, in the last analysis, in the executive? The right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt) has raised a doubt in regard to the words " .probable interruption." It may be said that there is always probability of an interruption of some particular service in the community; but if the Government took steps to meet a " probable interruption " that might exist only in its own imagination, its hasty action might accentuate the trouble. Notwithstanding the explanations given by the Government, I cannot see why the word ' ' essential ' ' is employed. The honest course would seem to be to eliminate it. We have been told that an essential service is practically any service whatever, and the very fact that the qualifying word " essential " is used will open up a wide field of litigation in the High Court. If it is claimed that full power is sought, why use a qualifying word that is bound to lead to trouble ? Even from a tory standpoint, the clause as drafted should be unacceptable, because it has been suggested that it will not give the Parliament or the Government unlimited power in certain directions to do everything possible - to meet an emergency, an objection similar in substance to that offered from this side, but based on different grounds. The fact that the present proposal is to be submitted to the people in conjunction with the previous measure will lead to the ignominious defeat of both. The Government ought to withdraw the bill. The opposition that has been expressed by honorable members, and the distrust that has been engendered, in the mind of the public as to the Government's intention, is such that to proceed with the measure would be to commit the country to the unnecessary expenditure of thousands of pounds. Several honorable members have suggested that the Government will not abuse any powers that may be conferred upon it. I, at any rate, am not prepared to entrust the Ministry with these powers. The Prime Minister, iu his second-reading speech, dismissed the bill in a few remarks occupying only a page of Hansard. His observations consisted of an attack upon the trade union movement of Australia, and there was no attempt to attach any other meaning of the* bill. There was no suggestion in his speech that the powers herein sought will- be exercised against vested interests, which, by cornering the markets and forcing up prices of commodities, unlawfully interrupt trade. We have been asked to trust this Government with this power ; but I have in mind a measure introduced three years ago, providing for the infliction of the death penalty on soldiers court martialled for military offences. A government that will introduce the iron heel of militarism ought not to ask the committee to accept its bland undertaking that it will not abuse any powers that may be granted to it. If the full trade and commerce power were ' sought, this bill would lose the guise of industrial conscription which it has at this moment, and its ambiguity and litigious nature would be eliminated. The Attorney-General (Mr. Latham) has admitted that if we took plenary trade and commerce power there would be no necessity for High Court interpretations or anything of that description. The clause as drafted will open up a big field of litigation. As the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt) has suggested, once this power was granted it could be abused to such au extent that a very grave dispute might arise between the Commonwealth and the States, leading, possibly, to actual violence, and the semblance of civil war. Some honorable members may ridicule that suggestion, but it cannot be denied that there is the possibility of a conflict occurring between the Governments of the Commonwealth and the States. In New South Wales, for example, there might be a government fresh from the people with an overwhelming mandate. The Federal Government might have received a majority of votes in the other five States, but a puerile minority in that- particular State. In such a case, it would have no moral right to interfere with the government of that State, but under the guise of protecting the public in case of actual or probable interruption of essential services, it could, under this power, override the authority of the State Government and interfere in a State dispute. It has been admitted that under this power the Commonwealth could take over the State railways ; in fact, it could assume the control and working of every government service, if it could show that such action was necessary to protect the public from interruption, of any essential service.
- The very wording of this clause is provocative.

- "Undoubtedly it is provocative, not only to the industrial workers of Australia, but also to the Governments of the States. It represents unification in the fullest sense of the term, for it will reduce the Governments of the States *to a condition of political bondage to the Federal Government. It is bound to be defeated, because the State Governments will not permit any overriding Federal, authority to interfere with the control of their instrumentalities, or any services over which they exercise any legislative jurisdiction. I have no doubt that the reason for the introduction of this industrial conscription referendum proposal is that five Labour Governments are in office in the States. Had there been six Nationalist Governments, the suggestion would not have been made that it is necessary to confer this power upon the Commonwealth. The last 25 years have not disclosed any such necessity. Different governments have succeeded in managing the affairs of the Commonwealth without request for such powers. The right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt), who is opposed to this bill, has been a member of some of them, and despite the personal respect we may have for him, we must admit that he has never displayed a spirit of benevolence towards strikers. The only inference to be drawn from the present attitude of the Government is, either that outside interests are dictating to it, or that that monumental example of futile legislation entitled the Crimes Act has proved, upon examination, to be invalid and unworkable. The Government is deserving of the strongest condemnation for compelling the continuance of the debate in the present discreditable circumstances, and rushing through legislation of such an important nature in the early hours of the morning. Doubtless, the hour is suited to the carrying out of dark and devious schemes designed to take away the liberty of the subject.
- It is a form of political murder.

- I agree with the right honorable gentleman. This is the right time, and the most suitable atmosphere for it. No reason has been given for these political tactics. The other place will not commence the discussion of the other bill until this afternoon. This measure is of infinitely greater importance, because it affects the basic principle of ourFederal system. I am surprised that honorable members opposite should tolerate the methods of the Government. They display the docility of cows grazing in a wellgrassed pasture. I have heard it whispered that the Government is afraid of losing its constitutional majority if it does not complete the measure at this sitting. There are 52 members of the Government party, and it does not speak we'll for the generalship of its leaders, or the loyalty of its members, if it is impossible to muster 38 votes for the bill. I protest against this protracted sitting, and the ambiguity and class character of the measure.

. - If we were consulting our own comfort, we should not be engaged at this hour in discussing such an important matter. I wish to pay a tribute to the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt) for the learned dissertation with which he favoured the committee this morning. Every thoughtful citizen will appreciate the cogency of his reasoning. I listened carefully to the reply of the right honorable the Prime Minister (Mr. Bruce) to the points raised by the right honorable member for Balaclava; but he did not effectively answer them. He advanced an argument which, on the face of it, was inconsistent and illogical. He said that if full powers over trade and commerce were taken, the exercise of them would bring this Commonwealth into conflict with the States.

speech.para: I cannot follow that reasoning, because, even if the power of the Commonwealth was concurrent with that of the States, where there was duplication, the power of the Commonwealth would be paramount. That being so, there can be no violation by the Commonwealth of a State statute, or any trespass on the domain of the States ; but the power which is sought to maintain essential services means that the Commonwealth will trespass upon what is essentially a State power. Therefore, the Commonwealth will come more directly into conflict with the States under this emergency power than in taking full power over trade and commerce. The right honorable the Prime Minister did not answer the questions of the right honorable member for Balaclava as to whether the essential services referred to in the bill are services essential to the life of the citizen, or essential to the life plus the comforts of the citizen, or essential to the economic services of the Commonwealth or a State. The Government has not established a case in support of the bill. I feel that the right honorable the Prime Minister evaded the important question asked by the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Scullin). His reasoning was far from clear, and his arguments were unconvincing. The plain question was submitted to him whether it was the intention of the Government, if a dislocation took place in an essential service, and if the responsibility for that dislocation rested on the employers, to take control of that service, and by his evasive answer he has shown that the Government will give a degree of consideration to employers which it will not extend to employees. That raises in my mind very grave fears concerning the possible unfair application of this power. If the bill is to be passed, I certainly think it should include a definition or qualification of the term "essential services." The Commonwealth has power to control interstate commerce or any service that comes within its province. This bill, if endorsed by the people and given effect, will conflict seriously with State interests. The States have now ample power to deal with services within their own borders, and any attempt to control them on the part of the Commonwealth will be rightly resented as an infringement of the sovereign rights of the States. If the State powers were incomplete and ineffective, I could quite understand the necessity for this legislation. In any case, the States can at present obtain the assistance of the Commonwealth in times of emergency. Honorable members on this side and several honorable members supporting the Government have pointed out the dangers associated with this bill. From past experience we know that these powers, if given to the Government, will be used to suppress and oppress the industrialists of this country. The object of the bill is to take from the workers the protection that they now enjoy under the State laws, especially when Labour Governments may be governing. If the Government had a sincere desire to apply it laws equitably and justly it would be prepared to take complete control of trade and commerce. The right honorable member for Balaclava and other honorable members have pointed out the ambiguity of the wording of the bill, and that in operation it is likely to infringe upon State rights, and lead to endless confusion in respect of the distribution of power between the Commonwealth and the States. I ask the right honorable member for Balaclava to persevere with the amendment that he has proposed, so that, in the event of its non-acceptance by the Government, we shall have on record the names of honorable members who are prepared to respect the sovereign rights of the States, so long as those rights are recognized in the Constitution. It is only right that the Commonwealth Parliament should maintain its prestige and supremacy in national matters, but, at the same time, we should be prepared to leave with the States the power of policing their own laws and matters of domestic concern.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to compliment the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt), who, by expressing his intention to move an important amendment, has caused consternation in the mind of the Prime Minister (Mr. Bruce). The object of the proposal is, I understand, to provide that the clause be amended so that the words " probable " and " essential services" shall be defined in such a way as to be easily interpreted by the High Court, the Parliament or the people. I do not think the Prime Minister has in any way removed the impression from the minds of many honorable members concerning the possibility of these words being interpreted so as to cause considerable litigation and expense. Why should we not endeavour to make the language of our legislation so clear that its meaning cannot be mistaken ? It is often wondered why Parliament employs such ambiguous language instead of using words or phrases which can be easily understood by even the most humble member of the community. As a member of this Parliament who will Have to explain the Government's proposals to my constituents, I desire some enlightenment.
- The meaning is clear.

- Neither the. Prime Minister nor the Attorney-General (Mk- Latham) have given us any assistance. If the Government really desire increased powers in this direction, they should ask the electors to vote on the question of whether the Parliament should be invested with power to make laws for the good government of the Commonwealth. That is clear and comprehensive. The Government is seeking power to protect the public interests in the case of actual or probable interruptions of essential services. The words "probable" and " essential services " are capable of very wide definition, and even the High Court judges may have difficulty in determining the intention of Parliament. There is considerable litigation over the meaning of many sections in State acts, particularly our lands acts, which of course are not so important as acts framed under the Commonwealth Constitution, which affect the whole of the people. If the constitutionality of legislation passed by this Parliament is contested in the High Court, _ we shall be told that as the act was passed by Parliament, we are all responsible. Does the Prime Minister sincerely desire this bill to pass, or is it only a subterfuge, a pretence of carrying out his so-called mandate from the people? I appreciate the effort of the right honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Watt) to make the language of this bill intelligible to the people. The ambiguity of the wording of our statutes is a most prolific cause of litigation. If the additional powers that are sought are granted by the people what time will. be allowed to elapse before legislation follows? It may be that the Prime Minister intends this measure only for window dressing purposes, and does not propose to submit legislation in exercise of the power that the bill confers. Certainly a large number of Ministerial members are not in accord with this bill, which leads nowhere. It seems to me that the Prime Minister, in bringing forward this measure, and the proposals in regard to the withdrawal of per capita payment to the States, is subtly designing to ensure the defeat of the other referendum bill. I understand that the right honorable member for Balaclava intends to move an amendment to make the wording of clause 2 more explicit. If he does so, he will receive my support.

.I endeavoured to follow carefully the explanation of this clause by the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General. The Prime Minister was more courteous than convincing. It may be that at this hour of the morning one becomes obstinate, or his mind becomes obtuse; at any rate, nothing said by the right honorable gentleman has altered my views in the slightest degree. The Attorney-General was neither courteous nor convincing, and I suggest that in future he might pay a little more respect to the committee when submitting matter for its consideration. None of us is too old or too young to learn. I hope that that will be taken in the spirit in which it is offered. I still say that it appears to me to be abundantly clear that the phrase " essential service " will leave much doubt in the minds of legislators, litigants, and judges. Unless something is added to the clause to show distinctly what was in the minds of its framers and sanctioners, much litigation is certain to follow. As to the power of intervention - that track through the forest of difficulty which I said was likely to lead to collision with the States - the responsibility is on the Government that proposed it. I think that we shall have to retrace our steps, for the bill seems to me to invite intimidation of the States, and retaliation by them. At the moment I content myself with moving -

speech.para: That the words " or probable " be left out.

If the clause were amended, it would still be possible for the Government to make any preparation it deemed necessary to meet the circumstances of an actual trouble; but it would be unwise to give it power to enter not merely the territory of a State, but also its area and orbit of authority, in the event of only a probable interruption. If the State authorities, which are nearer to the seat of the trouble, and so better able to form an opinion as to the seriousness of it, resented Commonwealth action, trouble would be certain to follow.

division.header.para: Question - That the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the clause - put. The committee divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

division.para: Bill reported without amendment; report, byleave, adopted.
That the bill be read a third time.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: - There being 39 ayes and 19 noes, I declare the motion agreed to by a statutory majority.
